posts.name: Bany Huang
posts.cooked:
Hi,  

I am part of the University of Michigan’s autonomous driving team. We are experimenting with the kraken for use next year over the neos but are encountering some challenges. Currently, we are using a simple odrive can to usb adapter (not the canivore). However, the motor fails to communicate with the can, displaying alternating red lights indefinitely. While our laptop can interact with the can bus via cmd, it appears the direct connection between the can and motor may be faulty.  

The attached code snippet and diagnostics indicate that the can bus is connected and running, but there is an issue during bring-up. This suggests a potential problem with the specific can to motor link.  

Please let me know if you need further clarification or additional details.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: Krakens can run off of normal cans too. However, you may experience a slight reduction in functionality. I don’t see a terminating resistor, so you would need to add one (120 ohms) on the opposite side of the can line. Additionally, you have the option to control it using PWM.
The image above, if accurate to the testing configuration, likely requires terminating the other end of the CAN bus for proper functionality.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
re a couple of things I would verify: 1. The onboard terminating resistor of the CAN to USB adapter should be enabled, and ideally the other end should also be terminated with a 120-ohm resistor. At CAN 2.0B speeds, things may work with only one terminating resistor with a short bus, but as you add more devices, that won't remain true. 2. Make sure you configure the USB to CAN adapter in SocketCAN to use the correct settings. Like other FRC devices, all our devices operate at 1 Mbps on CAN 2.0B, so you need to configure the adapter to match. We have an example script here to help with this setup. ``` The user's request was to clean up some technical text by removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements while preserving the original meaning. posts.name: Bany Huang
posts.cooked: Hi. Follow-up after we tried putting another terminating resistor. We don’t have 120 ohms, so we made one that's 125 ohms, which should be fine. Nothing else has changed, but we're still experiencing flashing red.

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked:
Here's the cleaned-up version:

"Have you sent a CAN frame with the adapter to test? What’s the result of candump can0? What’s the result of ip addr?

I would look at our non-FRC Linux user docs and Phoenix 6 example as a reference."

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked: The user asked whether ODrive is a motor controller and expressed surprise that it might expose a socket for a CAN interface. Upon reflection, it seems he meant that ODrive could have a socket designed for connecting to a CAN interface. This would allow it to communicate effectively with other systems. If ODrive indeed offers this feature, it should work well. However, if it doesn't, alternative solutions like a CANivore or CANable might be necessary. Additionally, the Kraken's built-in controller could be a suitable alternative depending on the desired setup, though options like NEO or Minion might offer standalone functionality if needed.

posts.name: Bany Huang
posts.cooked:
Hi,

Here is our candump and ipaddr:

candump:
can0  02046BC0   [6]  78 00 63 17 02 00
can0  02046D40   [6]  00 00 00 00 00 80
can0  02045080   [8]  00 00 00 60 00 00 00 00
can0  02045180   [8]  00 00 00 C0 52 19 1E 1A
can0  020451C0   [8]  00 00 80 30 00 00 00 00
can0  02045240   [8]  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
can0  02045280   [8]  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
can0  020452C0   [8]  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00
can0  02045300   [8]  00 00 00 5B 8B B3 00 00
can0  02045080   [8]  00 00 00 60 00 00 00 00

...goes on.

ipadd:

1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default qlen 1000
link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
inet 127.0.0.1/8 scope host lo
valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
inet6 ::1/128 scope host noprefixroute
valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
2: wlp1s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc fq_codel state UP group default qlen 1000
link/ether 3c:06:30:02:49:b8 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
inet 35.0.27.222/20 brd 35.0.31.255 scope global dynamic noprefixroute wlp1s0f0
valid_lft 1020sec preferred_lft 1020sec
inet6 fe80::dcf1:5c84:b541:60d6/64 scope link noprefixroute
valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
5: can0: <NOARP,UP,LOWER_UP,ECHO> mtu 16 qdisc pfifo_fast state UP group default qlen 10
link/can

We are experiencing alternating orange lights, similar to our previous setup. According to the documentation, one possible reason for this issue is the lack of a "robot controller" connected to the bus. This leaves us wondering: Can our current setup, such as using only a laptop, suffice for the CAN bus, or do we require a dedicated controller like the Roborio? Additionally, since our CAN adapter is produced by ODrive but we are not utilizing the actual ODrive motor controller, we are curious whether this configuration is adequate or if it presents a problem.

Furthermore, we have been provided with a link to the ODrive USB-CAN Adapter, which is described as a plug-and-play device suitable for controlling ODrives and other CAN devices. However, it remains unclear if this product is essential for our current setup or merely an additional option.

Our `candump` logs indicate active CAN traffic, suggesting that the network is operational. The alternating orange lights may point to an error condition or communication issue within the CAN network. Without further diagnostic information, it is challenging to identify the precise cause. Nonetheless, based on the documentation, integrating a robot controller might stabilize the network or enable necessary functionalities.

In summary, we need clarification on whether the absence of a robot controller is the root cause of our issues and whether the existing setup, using just the laptop, is sufficient or if a dedicated controller like the Roborio is required. Additionally, we must confirm whether using the ODrive-manufactured CAN adapter without the motor controller affects our system's functionality.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Alternating orange means your CAN bus should be fine, the device just isn’t seeing a robot program with an enable frame. In a non-FRC context, you need to manually feed the enable frame. Also, make sure your device isn’t FRC locked (factory default the device from Phoenix Tuner X).

posts.name: Bany Huang
posts.cooked: With the Tuner, I’m getting “no device detected on can bus” when I try. After connecting the system and ensuring the CAN bus is properly connected via Linux, I open the tuner.
